title: ‘Fighting fit’ mum dies of sudden aneurysm as husband fights incurable cancer
text:
Sharon Bithell, 44, suffered a sudden brain aneurysm (Picture: BPM Media)

A ‘fighting fit’ mum-of-one has died of a brain aneurysm as her husband battles incurable cancer.

Sharon Bithell, 44, was preparing to be the ‘breadwinner’ of the household while partner Dave, 55, underwent chemotherapy sessions this year.

She was rushed to hospital on October 13 after suffering a sudden aneurysm at home, and died just 10 days later.

The pair had just celebrated their 20th anniversary and share one son together, Harry, 12.

Dave said Sharon had been as ‘fit as a flea’ before suffering the aneurysm, which saw her be airlifted to a hospital in Southampton on the Sunday.

Her family said she was as ‘fit as a flea’ (Picture: BPM Media)

As they waited for emergency services, locals nearby performed CPR on her, with medics later saying she would have died without their quick-thinking.

However, David said hospital staff knew by the Wednesday that she wasn’t going to survive.

He told BirminghamLive: ‘I had the best years of my life with Sharon, we were best friends, we loved each other.

‘I absolutely adored her, she was the love of my life and I thought we would have many years together still. We had hope for the future.’

He continued: ‘She was very fit and active and a fantastic mum to Harry. At work, she was like a mother figure to a lot of people that worked there.

Dave Bithell is battling incurable cancer (Picture: BPM MEDIA)

‘Aneurysms just come on really quickly, it can just happen like that – and it did – it just happened out the blue.

‘I’m up and down like a yo-yo, one minute I’m alright, the next I’m in floods of tears. It’s like a bad dream. It’s the last thing we expected.

‘Sharon was going to be the breadwinner when I was going through all my treatment, so we just didn’t have any indication of this happening.’

Catering team leader Sharon was born in Chelmsley Wood, and later moved to Solihull, where she attended Lode Heath School.

She then settled down in Southampton with Dave and the pair focused on raising their son.

The couple have a son, Harry, together (Picture: BPM MEDIA)

Dave was later diagnosed with incurable stage four mantle cell lymphoma and started chemotherapy treatment in the hope of extending his life by up to a decade.

However, he says it’s possible he could be given just two more years to live.

He is unable to work until his treatment finishes in July next year, and both his and Sharon’s parents have moved into the area to help the family out.

Dave said: ‘[The cancer] is incurable so at some point, I might go into remission.

‘One of the consultants said to me: “If you had this five years ago your chances of survival would be poor, but now its quite likely that we can give you another five years.”

‘Maybe I might get ten years, I might get five – I might get two, we just don’t know.’

Family friend Louise Facey set up a GoFundMe page shortly before Sharon died, which has so-far raised nearly £9,500.

Before her death, they recorded her progress, with Dave reported as saying: ‘I only got 20 minutes with Sharon awake today in four hours, but it was worth it.

‘I put the earphones in and played her these tunes below. Sharon was smiling, singing badly and her leg was going like Billy-o. It was pure joy.’

Louise also noted that Sharon had ‘put her name on the organ donation list twice’ because it was the ‘kind of person she was’.
